story:
About Us

We are a Hawaiian food truck serving authentic island flavors with a modern twist. 

We first launched in the Fall of 2015. Our goal then was to introduce the concept of Hawaiian street food to the people of Columbus. With our new venture we are aiming to have more traditional Hawaiian dishes along with a zero waste, go green initiative.

Aloha 'Aína stands for "love of the land", which is exactly what inspired us to create this truck. Our plan is to launch the new Aloha truck by April of this year. Your contributions will go toward purchasing solar panels, a battery bank, and converting the truck to biodiesel fuel.

 

Mission Statement:

"Aloha ‘Aína, helping clean and green our community one meal at a time!"

 

Project Goals

We will be installing solar panels to the roof & battery bank in our new Aloha 'Aina truck, with the goal of becoming a more Eco-friendly vehicle. For overcast days, we will charge the battery bank at our commercial kitchen overnight. On a full charge, the battery bank will allow us to run off-grid for up to 8 hours. In turn this helps mititagate any environmental impact, which is extremely important to our commitment for conservation.

By doing this we hope to set an example and create a trend amongst food truck owners. The message is clear, the time is now for us to clean and green our environment! This project alone will reduce daily waste by up to 95% and ultimately reduce our carbon footprint.

You will be a part of a unique experience that will show how a few small changes can shift the whole trajectory of our planet. Help us save the earth one Aloha dish at a time!

 

Zero Waste Initiative

With your help our new truck is going green! As a part of this initiative we have switched over to use biodegradable serving containers and the use of recycling bins. Along with area businesses such as Blank Slate Coffee and Frankie's Pizza, we have partnered with the city of Gahanna to build compost bins to dispose of organic food waste. This will produce plant fertilizer for the City of Gahanna Parks and Recreation. 

Giving back to a community in which supports our vision so vigorously,  is extremely important to us. This is why at the end of each day we will gather all of the remaining food we have and donate it to G.R.I.N. (Gahanna Residents In Need).

We are committed to engaging with the community and our future generation by promoting a positive and constructive atmosphere. We want our focus to be on strengthening the community and supporting those who are in need the most.

 

Take A Look At Some Of The Reviews From Our Facebook and Yelp Pages!

"Sara is definitely spreading the Aloha from the 808 in the Buckeye State with her awesome twist on Hawaiian/Pacific Rim cuisine. Keep up the ONOlicious food and I promise to one day bring the uke and jam some Hawaiian Mele. MAHALO NUI LOA"         -Francis Llacuna (Facebook page review)

 

"Simply delicious! I was lucky enough to try this cuisine at Seventh Son Brewery today and LOVED it! A delicious and light option for lunch or dinner! Fun flavors paired with an assortment of proteins to please any palate! The fried tofu is to die for!"               -Morgan Crudwell  (Facebook page review)

"When you think of a food truck, fresh food isn't always what comes to mind.  This truck is definitely an exception - their food is always fresh!  It is also pretty healthy!  They have a lot of different options and everything is very good.  I have tried the fresh rice bowl, the pineapple bun and the Hawaiian BBQ bun and enjoyed them all. Service is quick and prices are appropriate for the quality and quantity of food being purchased.  I am glad they exist and look forward to the next when I see them in my hood!"

-Erica R. via Yelp

"Had the chance to try out this truck while on a Columbus Food Adventure. It was parked at Seventh Son, one of my favorite breweries in town. I had their banh mi sandwich and was blown away! It was the perfect blend of flavor and texture. It also had cilantro on it and I'm a sucker for cilantro."       -Mandi C via Yelp

Video: Villa Creative (Justin-Paul Villanueva)
 

Contact Information

  • Email: aloha.aina614@gmail.com

 

© Anthony Valentine Jr.

story:
Meet the Artist: Mellow D

Melodie Walenius is a well rounded musician that turned her creativity into an edible medium and now pours her passion into sugar and chocolate. She is an award winning and innovative chocolatier and sugar artist. She teaches classes using specialty chocolate techniques, sculpting with chocolate and cake decorating with modeling chocolate. She has her own line of products that are distributed worldwide. She has been featured in the Virginia Pilot, Richmond Times and Virginia Bride Magazine. She is a baking partner for Icing Smiles. She lives in Midlothian, Virginia with her husband and four children.

  • Sweetastic is preparing to launch international distribution of our signature line of modeling chocolate! But, before we can make that happen, we have to secure the four corners of the US with adequate distribution, production facilities and manpower. 
  • By supporting the Sweetastic Modeling Chocolate campaign, you will help us initiate our first brick and mortar production facility, and stock it with all the supplies needed to make Sweetastic an international brand.

What is Sweetastic Modeling Chocolate?

  • SMC is a soft chocolate dough used to decorate cakes and cookies, wrap cakes, create sculptures and edible flowers.


What We Need & What You Get

Break it down for folks in more detail:

  • Building out a commercial kitchen facility can be quite costly. Our initial funding campaign will simply allow us to "break ground" and provide equipment and supplies to get us started. We anticipate sales to carry the rest of the expenses. 
  • SUPPORTER PERKS: We have some way cool stuff!!! Sculpting tools, MODELING CHOCOLATE, Video Tutorials and MORE!
  • If we don't meet our goal to "start digging" we will use whatever money we do raise to purchase supplies. Our best selling 6oz tubs of modeling chocolate are on FREEZE right now. So, we will order 5,000 of those tubs so we can fill all the orders waiting so patiently for them to arrive! And, of course, we will be stocking up the ingredients needed to make all our wonderful colors!

The Impact

Your contribution to our campaign will allow us to not only take Sweetastic modeling chocolate outside the US, but also to expand the personnel of our little company! 

  • Pastry artists worldwide will be able to impress their clients with a great tasting product that is easy to use and readily available!
  • When we open a production facility, we will be able to hire a staff! Mellow D has been making every ounce by hand, by herself! She's ready to create new jobs and hire new hands to help manufacture her signature product.

Risks & Challenges

With every business adventure their is always some element of contingency. We realize that nothing is guaranteed.

  • We could not raise enough money.
  • We could lose connections with international suppliers and distributors.
  • We could not be able to contract with a facility.
However,
  • We will use whatever money we raise to continue production and the growth of the company to meet our clients needs efficiently.
  • We will still be able to revamp our packaging to utilize different suppliers. 
  • We still have our current operation kitchen that can be utilized until a commercial facility is secured. 

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't contribute, you can still help:

  • Help us get the word out and make some noise about our campaign.
  • Use the Indiegogo share tools!
  • Pray for a successful campaign! Faith has brought us this far!

Philippians 3:14 I press on toward the goal for the prize of the upward call of God in Christ Jesus.

We anticipate sales to carry the rest of the expenses.  SUPPORTER PERKS: We have some way cool stuff!!! Sculpting tools, MODELING CHOCOLATE, Video Tutorials and MORE! If we don't meet our goal to "start digging" we will use whatever money we do raise to purchase supplies. Our best selling 6oz tubs of modeling chocolate are on FREEZE right now. So, we will order 5,000 of those tubs so we can fill all the orders waiting so patiently for them to arrive! And, of course, we will be stocking up the ingredients needed to make all our wonderful colors!    The Impact Your contribution to our campaign will allow us to not only take Sweetastic modeling chocolate outside the US, but also to expand the personnel of our little company!   Pastry artists worldwide will be able to impress their clients with a great tasting product that is easy to use and readily available!
When we open a production facility, we will be able to hire a staff! Mellow D has been making every ounce by hand, by herself! She's ready to create new jobs and hire new hands to help manufacture her signature product.    Risks & Challenges  With every business adventure their is always some element of contingency. We realize that nothing is guaranteed.  We could not raise enough money.
We could lose connections with international suppliers and distributors.
We could not be able to contract with a facility.

However,
 We will use whatever money we raise to continue production and the growth of the company to meet our clients needs efficiently.
We will still be able to revamp our packaging to utilize different suppliers. 
We still have our current operation kitchen that can be utilized until a commercial facility is secured.     Other Ways You Can Help If you can't contribute, you can still help:  Help us get the word out and make some noise about our campaign. Use the Indiegogo share tools!
Pray for a successful campaign! Faith has brought us this far!

Philippians 3:14 I press on toward the goal for the prize of the upward call of God in Christ Jesus.

story:
Our Story

In May of 2015, fire caused the closure of the historic Ronsheimer building, leaving Penngrove without a place to buy staples like milk or bread. As the building lay dormant and empty, Rebecca McDowell dreamed of providing a local market and community hub in the heart of downtown Penngrove. As the building was carefully restored, Rebecca and her husband, Evan, with long time friends, Joe and Shaina Ferraro, collaborated to create the new Penngrove Market. 

Together, this team has decades of experience in grocery stores, prepared foods and customer service. Passionate about locally-sourced ingredients and seasonal cooking, their mission is to create a neighborhood grocery store that nurtures connection with the community, the environment, local farmers and makers.

What We Need & What You Get

We are working hard to open the market, but we need your help! To provide the delicious  prepared foods and fresh local produce our community desires, we need the tools and equipment to prepare them. The money we raise will go directly to procuring ovens, mixers, juicers, refrigeration, and shelving, that will allow us to showcase the bounty of Sonoma County.

One of our first big purchases was a wood-fire oven from Mugnaini, a local oven builder and one of the best in the business! With this oven in our kitchen, Chef Joe and his crew are able to make scrumptious pizzas, calzones, and roasted meats and vegetables. Have you ever tried a piadine? Piadine is wood-fired Italian flatbread and salad wrap with infinite possibilities of seasonal combinations. Lunch is on us if you contribute and choose the “T-shirt & Pizza”! Or have you always wanted to learn how to cook in a wood-fired oven? Contribute and enjoy a class with Chef Joe! We’ve got all levels of contributions and prizes and we appreciate any amount you’re able to help Penngrove Market!

The Impact

Your contribution to our campaign will help Penngrove Market provide:

  • a central hub for gathering and connecting with the community
  • employment for members of the community
  • a marketplace for local farmers and artisans to share their product without having to ship it far away
  • healthy delicious foods and household necessities for people that would otherwise need to leave town to find them
  • the opportunity for money to stay within Sonoma County and improve our local economy
  • benefits to our environment by lessening the distance our food travels

Become a Community Lender! 

Our vision is to create a community market in the truest sense. This means that everyone in our community has an opportunity to make this dream a reality. In addition to our campaign, we are looking for local investors to lend capital at  competitive interest rates. This will help us fund the needed construction and infrastructure to build out the market. If you are interested in putting your money to work in a grass-roots local market, and reaping the benefits of receiving interest, alongside building an asset for our community, we invite you to connect with us and explore the possibilities. Contact us for more information.

Other Ways You Can Help

  • Share this campaign on social media by clicking on the links above!
  • Apply to work at Penngrove Market and become part of our team!
  • Buy a ticket to the Grand Opening Party and give it to a Friend! 

Together we can build Penngrove Market!

story:
Summary

A Cat Cafe and Rehoming Centre, to be opened on the Isle of Wight. The idea is for customers to relax surrounded by the cats, as our furry friends learn to adapt to human company again, or even for the first time. They will all be up for permanent adoption, to help them find their forever homes once they've been vet treated, neutered, microchipped and vaccinated. Please help us fund this venture, and help save our local cats. 

Visit www.theshreddedcouch.co.uk for more information.

Who am I?

My name is Jules Buckland; I am a 26 year old homeowner, born and bred on the Isle of Wight. I have lived with cats my whole life, and experienced first hand the love that they can bring.

Branded as a 'Crazy Cat Lady', I decided to study on a Business degree with the Open University to bring this concept to life and successfully help the local animal shelters to keep strays off the streets. 

I have studied 50 hours a week on top of full time work and overtime for nearly 4 years to make this happen, and I just need your help to finally set up and launch.

How will this cafe work?

Cats will be rescued, vet treated, neutered, vaccinated, and chipped, before being temporarily housed in the cafe where customers can book slots to visit. There will be 2 options: £5 per person for a 60 minute slot, or £6.50 per person for a 90 minute slot. There will be a delicious selection of food and drink at affordable prices, catering for various dietary needs, offering a perfect opportunity to just relax and enjoy the company of the cats.

The cats will be available for permanent adoption through a process starting with an application form, following similar procedures to that of the animal shelters. 

Why?

Our local animal shelters are operating at maximum capacity, and there are still several cats struggling on the streets. This cafe offers another venue of temporary housing, helping to rescue and protect more cats. 

Risks and Challenges

The main challenge is raising enough capital to launch, which is where you come in! If we can raise the required finances, we will be able to offer the cats a warm and loving shelter while they charm their way into their forever families. 

Another challenge is our competitors, but on an isolated island and a popular tourist location, I feel we will compete well. We will be one of the only UK cat cafes to offer rehoming too, which gives us a competitive edge. 

The main risk is not being able to sustain the business, which is the case for every start up. This was the motivation to study a business degree, which I feel has given me the skills, knowledge and confidence to  make this business thrive. 

Another risk is that we are seen to be neglecting the welfare of our cats. Please do not see this as an alternative to a forever family home, but instead an alternative to being caged in an animal shelter. The welfare of our cats is the most important aspect of this business, as the idea is to keep them safe and build up their confidence around people before finding a suitable family. There will be a set of house rules in place to ensure the safety of our cats and customers at all times. 

So where does the money go?

Your funding goes towards securing a suitable premises for the cafe, where the cats have sufficient space and customers can access it with ease. Once these premises are secured, funding will help to kit it out to keep the cats happy, and the customers comfortable, as well as helping towards relevant licenses. It will help get this idea off the ground, and offer you a relaxing environment to enjoy the company of the cats without the responsibility and commitment of having one at home. 

How else can I help?

Please get the word out to help me reach my target. Share on social media, tell all your friends and family, and be sure to pop your head in once we open!

story:
MORE THAN BEAUTIFUL

Doing our small part to take care of this beautiful world. Our bags are made from organic materials and certified backyard compostable, so you can feel good about where it came from and where it's going to.
 

 

DESIGNED FOR EVERYONE

We wanted to make it easy for you to find and steep a tea you'll love. That's why we've put all the information you need right on the front of the bag! 

 

SHOWING OUR ROOTS

On the back of the new bag, you'll not only find the story of Chad's Chai in words, but also in a beautiful tapestry. From a childhood in Spain to pots of chai on the stove, with little nods to the friends and family that have helped us along the way.
 

 

TELL YOUR FRIENDS


 

 

SPONSORED + 

SUPPORTED BY

story:
Our Story and Vision.

For as long as I can remember, I've wanted to open a bakery. I grew up with an aunt (Joi) who was in my mind the worlds best baker. Everything she made seemed effortless, always amazing  flavor and exact consistency with every batch of goodies created at the time.  This will for making great food stayed with me and one day I developed an outstanding cheesecake.

Making cheesecakes for more than just my family began when someone I knew remodeled a Minneapolis known bar, The Poodle Club, and turned it into McMahon's Irish Pub on East Lake Street. The Pub was the heart of so many people for a short time and my cheesecakes was the only featured dessert on the menu. Locals loved my cheesecakes and the pub family couldn't get enough as well. After a devastating fire to the building that housed the pub, the pub was lost. To anyone reading this who was a part of the pub in any way, I send you a hug and think of you often.  

After what happened at the Pub, I continued on with my career as a Senior Paralegal at a large law firm in downtown Minneapolis. I never gave up on the idea of some day opening my very own bakery. 

Fast forward to 2013. I had the amazing opportunity to begin working for Prince by selling merchandise during events held at Paisley Park. I took it upon myself to bring in cheesecakes for my friends who worked with him, because I knew long rehearsals would surely make for a welcome dessert at the end of the day. I also hoped a certain purple someone would find my cheesecakes in the fridge to enjoy as well. To my pleasant surprise, he wouldn’t be quiet for long.

One day, Prince tweeted this from his official Twitter account at the time, @3RDEYEGIRL:

 

Prince found my cheesecakes and he enjoyed them. Clearly he was pleased with my creations! 

Soon after, invitations to Paisley Park began to "CHEESECAKE FUNK" - he created a signature name for my cheesecakes, another sign that he was pleased with my product. With that, Cheesecake Funk was created associated to my cheesecakes. 

Cheesecake Funk has gained a global following and interest. My cheesecakes have been requested by people from all over the world: United States, Central America, Europe, France, Germany, Japan, Netherlands and Turkey. Once the doors of the Cheesecake Funk bakery opens, it will soon become a must-stop destination.  To date, thousands of people from all over the world have tried Cheesecake Funk and it brings great joy making so many people happy with cheesecake goodness.

The fun, edgy and unique logo for Cheesecake Funk was created by Art Director, Martin Homent, who is based in London. Martin is the creator of The Many Faces of Prince collection. His artwork was also featured on HITANDRUN Phase One & Two, which was Prince’s last two albums. It is an honor to have had Martin create such an amazing and unique logo for the Cheesecake Funk brand.

Donations are sought to help secure a bakery location and get the Cheesecake Funk bakery up and running. With your help, the bakery will open and grow to be an amazing bakery and catering destination in Minnesota - something special for dessert lovers from all over the world.

A sincere thank you for taking the time to read this vision and thank you in advance for your support. Every person who helps this vision come to life will have their name added to our Founders Wall at the bakery as well. A unique and beautiful piece of art that will forever show our thanks and appreciation! 

Vanessa Drews, Owner and Baker at Cheesecake Funk.

story:
Our passion for cider and wine runs deep. So deep, in fact, it prompted a cross-country move to New England and literally buying a farm to pave the way to our dream of creating dry, refreshing, and well-crafted cider and wine. 

Leo has been making cider and wine as a hobby for over 10 years; Luna Negra Cidery and Winery would allow us to professionally produce and share his favorite cider and wine recipes with the world. 

By converting our Quonset hut into a production and cellar space, we will be able carefully scale production up to a commercial level. The cidery and winery will use locally sourced, New England ingredients like cider and dessert apples, cold-hardy wine grapes, and hops — much of which will be grown on our own farm! 

Initially, the cider offerings will include a traditional dry cider, a dry-hopped variety, and a few seasonal selections. The winery will focus on crafting dry, bright, sparkling white and rosé offerings, as well as the occasional fruit wine to take advantage of Maine’s berry abundance!

Leo’s extensive experience in the industry brings a qualified skillset, an intimate knowledge of the trade, and an undeniable passion for the product to Luna Negra. But taking on such an endeavor is not just labor-intensive — it’s also expensive. Your contribution will help create the production and fermentation space, upgrade any necessary equipment, and generally help us get our product to market. With your support, and the blood, sweat, and tears of our family and friends, this dream is destined to take root and grow into a flourishing business.

Luna Negra is a huge undertaking, but we are so very excited to get started. The last decade of Leo’s life has been building up to this moment, and we’re ready to hit the ground running.

Your generous contributions will fund:

Production Build - $8,500
Fermenters - $3,000
Pump: $4,000
General production equipment (i.e., hoses, clamps, cleaning supplies): $1,500

3-bay Sink: $400
C02 Tank: $400
Kegs: $2,500

Bottles: $2,500

Legal Fees / Licensing / Labeling: $2,200

Total: $25,000

Reaching the Indigogo goal of $25,000 allows for the construction of the production and fermentation space, perhaps even in time to take advantage of the fall harvest! If the campaign reaches our stretch goal of $35,000, we will be able to acquire barrels for aging, a heat pump for temperature control, and will help us to build our own press.

We have some wonderful donation rewards! Please feel free to reach out to us with any questions. Visit our website while it’s under construction, and follow us @LunaNegraMaine on Facebook and Instagram.

We appreciate your taking the time to learn more about us. And thank you in advance for your support. Salud!

story:
Please help support a small expedition of Pacific Northwest farmers and farm educators headed to northern Italy in January to learn more about both production methods and culinary uses for this quintessentially Italian crop, and to bring back that information for growers, cooks and eaters.

The Expedition is being organized and led by Italian farmer Myrtha Zierock of Foradori Winery and Farm in Mezzolombardo, Italy, and Lane Selman of the Culinary Breeding Network in Portland, Oregon. We will visit production farms, seed companies and radicchio breeders throughout the Veneto region for five days. The expedition will culminate in a public event and radicchio celebration called Giàz (meaning ‘ice’ in the Trentino dialect) at Foradori.

Outcomes will include articles, photographs, video and presentations for the public, all focused on increasing understanding of radicchio production and culinary usage. Information will be shared at the third annual Sagra di Radicchio event in Seattle, WA in 2020 which we hope to expand into a multi-day conference this coming year.

Sponsorship will help cover travel expenses and the development of educational materials for the primary documentarians on the trip: Lane Selman of The Culinary Breeding Network, Josh Volk of Slow Hand Farm Consulting, and Shawn Linehan of Shawn Linehan Photography.

Background - Radicchio is a cool season vegetable that originated and is still widely grown in the Veneto region of northeastern Italy, a climate of annual mean temperatures, and latitude very similar to those of the Pacific Northwest. It is a promising winter crop as it overwinters in the field and holds well in storage, providing a locally grown alternative to lettuce shipped from warmer regions during the colder months. Numerous farmers in Oregon and Washington are interested in growing radicchio, but have production questions on variety selection, seeding and transplanting timing, cultivation, harvest, forcing techniques and storage. Little of this detailed information is available in the US and the best way to acquire details by directly visiting the farmers growing these crops in Italy. An initial visit to radicchio seed breeders in 2014 was an invaluable introduction to many basics practices that were not commonly known in the US and this second trip will build on that information by visiting more growers in the region and documenting their practices.

According to growers in the northwest and northeastern US, radicchio demand has increased exponentially over the past decade and recent years. Local Roots Farm in Duvall, WA has reported a 900% increase over the last decade and a doubling in sales in the past year alone. Radicchio sales currently account for 12% of their total annual sales to restaurants, and they expect that growth to continue. Hayshaker Farm in Walla Walla, WA have seen sales increase 250% from 2017 to 2018 and they also see demand continuing to grow.

On the East coast, Kitchen Garden Farm in western Massachusetts has doubled sales in the last year with $30,000 in radicchio sales for 2018 making the crop a significant part of the farm income, not just something novel and fun. Since 2017, Kitchen Garden Farm has been primarily selling vegetables through distributors, and directly to stores and restaurants, in NYC, Boston, and Providence. More than 60% of their 2018 radicchio was sold to NYC through Natoora and Myers Produce.

In the US, the California-grown, round, red Chioggia type is the most commonly found radicchio on grocery store shelves. Pacific Northwest growers are producing a much wider variety of radicchio types including Treviso Precoce, Treviso Tardivo, Castelfranco, Lusia, Verona, Rose, Puntarelle, Grumolo and more. Each has a unique appearance, flavor, texture and culinary purpose. And each have their own set of growing methods which we hope to learn more about during the “Radicchio Expedition in Veneto, Italy 2020”.

 

LANE SELMAN AND THE CULINARY BREEDING NETWORK

The Culinary Breeding Network is an initiative created by Lane Selman with a mission to break down the walls between breeders and eaters to improve agricultural and culinary quality. Read more about the Network at www.culinarybreedingnetwork.com.

 

SHAWN LINEHAN

Shawn Linehan has been photographing small-scale farmers and seed breeders since 2008 and has photographed at all CBN’s Variety Showcases. Traveling twice to Japan with Stacey Givens of The Side Yard Farm & Kitchen sparked a desire to photograph more farming and seed breeding on an international level. Your support would help her to reach that goal and help document this important cultural and informational exchange that will benefit our community. See more photos at www.shawnlinehan.com

 

JOSH VOLK

Josh is vegetable farmer
and the author of the book “Compact Farms: 15 Proven Plans for Market Farms on 5 Acres or Less” from Storey Publishing. He has been a Slow Food member for more than 20 years, and is also involved with the Slow Tools movement which seeks to further Slow Food production through appropriate technology development and sharing. He currently farms
in Portland, Oregon at Cully Neighborhood Farm. You can learn more at www.slowhandfarm.com
story_txt:
Please help support a small expedition of Pacific Northwest farmers and farm educators headed to northern Italy in January to learn more about both production methods and culinary uses for this quintessentially Italian crop, and to bring back that information for growers, cooks and eaters.
The Expedition is being organized and led by Italian farmer Myrtha Zierock of Foradori Winery and Farm in Mezzolombardo, Italy, and Lane Selman of the Culinary Breeding Network in Portland, Oregon. We will visit production farms, seed companies and radicchio breeders throughout the Veneto region for five days. The expedition will culminate in a public event and radicchio celebration called Giàz (meaning ‘ice’ in the Trentino dialect) at Foradori.
Outcomes will include articles, photographs, video and presentations for the public, all focused on increasing understanding of radicchio production and culinary usage. Information will be shared at the third annual Sagra di Radicchio event in Seattle, WA in 2020 which we hope to expand into a multi-day conference this coming year.
Sponsorship will help cover travel expenses and the development of educational materials for the primary documentarians on the trip: Lane Selman of The Culinary Breeding Network, Josh Volk of Slow Hand Farm Consulting, and Shawn Linehan of Shawn Linehan Photography.
Background - Radicchio is a cool season vegetable that originated and is still widely grown in the Veneto region of northeastern Italy, a climate of annual mean temperatures, and latitude very similar to those of the Pacific Northwest. It is a promising winter crop as it overwinters in the field and holds well in storage, providing a locally grown alternative to lettuce shipped from warmer regions during the colder months. Numerous farmers in Oregon and Washington are interested in growing radicchio, but have production questions on variety selection, seeding and transplanting timing, cultivation, harvest, forcing techniques and storage. Little of this detailed information is available in the US and the best way to acquire details by directly visiting the farmers growing these crops in Italy. An initial visit to radicchio seed breeders in 2014 was an invaluable introduction to many basics practices that were not commonly known in the US and this second trip will build on that information by visiting more growers in the region and documenting their practices.
According to growers in the northwest and northeastern US, radicchio demand has increased exponentially over the past decade and recent years. Local Roots Farm in Duvall, WA has reported a 900% increase over the last decade and a doubling in sales in the past year alone. Radicchio sales currently account for 12% of their total annual sales to restaurants, and they expect that growth to continue. Hayshaker Farm in Walla Walla, WA have seen sales increase 250% from 2017 to 2018 and they also see demand continuing to grow.
On the East coast, Kitchen Garden Farm in western Massachusetts has doubled sales in the last year with $30,000 in radicchio sales for 2018 making the crop a significant part of the farm income, not just something novel and fun. Since 2017, Kitchen Garden Farm has been primarily selling vegetables through distributors, and directly to stores and restaurants, in NYC, Boston, and Providence. More than 60% of their 2018 radicchio was sold to NYC through Natoora and Myers Produce.
In the US, the California-grown, round, red Chioggia type is the most commonly found radicchio on grocery store shelves. Pacific Northwest growers are producing a much wider variety of radicchio types including Treviso Precoce, Treviso Tardivo, Castelfranco, Lusia, Verona, Rose, Puntarelle, Grumolo and more. Each has a unique appearance, flavor, texture and culinary purpose. And each have their own set of growing methods which we hope to learn more about during the “Radicchio Expedition in Veneto, Italy 2020”.
 
LANE SELMAN AND THE CULINARY BREEDING NETWORK
The Culinary Breeding Network is an initiative created by Lane Selman with a mission to break down the walls between breeders and eaters to improve agricultural and culinary quality. Read more about the Network at www.culinarybreedingnetwork.com.
 
SHAWN LINEHAN
Shawn Linehan has been photographing small-scale farmers and seed breeders since 2008 and has photographed at all CBN’s Variety Showcases. Traveling twice to Japan with Stacey Givens of The Side Yard Farm & Kitchen sparked a desire to photograph more farming and seed breeding on an international level. Your support would help her to reach that goal and help document this important cultural and informational exchange that will benefit our community. See more photos at www.shawnlinehan.com
 
JOSH VOLK
Josh is vegetable farmerand the author of the book “Compact Farms: 15 Proven Plans for Market Farms on 5 Acres or Less” from Storey Publishing. He has been a Slow Food member for more than 20 years, and is also involved with the Slow Tools movement which seeks to further Slow Food production through appropriate technology development and sharing. He currently farmsin Portland, Oregon at Cully Neighborhood Farm. You can learn more at www.slowhandfarm.com

story:
Every parent hopes their children will be happy and enjoy life. But what if something totally unexpected alters these dreams forever.

Well, that is exactly what happened one cold night in February many years ago. I kissed my very normal 2 1/2 yr old little boy good night not knowing Danny would be spending the next week in intensive care. The best guess from Danny's team of doctors was that some infection invaded his brain and destroyed lots of tissue. When Danny finally came home he was like a new born baby. He couldn't walk, sit up, hold a cup, talk, etc. He had to relearn everything.

Ok. So now what? Like many families of children with disabilities our lives became engulfed with endless paperwork, doctor's appointments, therapy of all kinds, and a slow realization that the agencies designed to help often do not.

When Danny was in middle school a friend and I were thinking about job opportunities that would fit our children's abilities. We came up with some pretty crazy ideas but as special needs parents we have learned to think "outside the box". For me, the craziest idea was becoming a kettle corn vendor! I had never even heard of kettle corn. So in 2011 our popcorn adventure began.  

Danny loves making popcorn! Kettle corn was a great summer job but as graduation approached we wondered how we could turn Danny's love of popcorn into a lifetime opportunity. Employment for people with intellectual and developmental disabilities is less than 10% so my motivation to find something that fit Danny's abilities which he would enjoy was unstoppable. By building on Danny's interests and abilities we expanded into a gourmet popcorn company ~ Poppin' Z's Gourmet Popcorn in 2014.

Who knew in a few short years we would have over fifty gourmet popcorn flavors? Baconator, Caramel Cashew, Snickerdoodle, Mint Chocolate, Tuxedo, Birthday Cake, Green & Gold ......(hungry yet?) 

Our business has grown to include our online store with a variety of size options plus gift ideas; popcorn buffets which are great for parties, weddings, employee appreciation; corporate gift or trade show ideas; plus fundraising which is a great way for us to support groups in our community. We have shipped popcorn from home in Green Bay, Wisconsin to Texas, from Washington state to Florida.

We didn't know what to expect when we started our popcorn business but as sales continue to grow we are able to bring this employment opportunity to other people just like Danny. In 2017 we were fortunate to hire work experience special education students from a local high school during our crazy busy holiday season. What an awesome experience for all! Since the beginning we've dreamed about employing others facing similar challenges to Danny's and are so grateful our sales allowed us to expand our workforce, even if it was only temporarily. (at least for now?)

So again we're thinking "outside the box" as to how we can turn this seasonal employment for people with intellectual or developmental disabilities into a year round opportunity. Danny wouldn't have the skills the doctors said he would never acquire if not for Danny's "team of villagers". We believe in the power of community helping each other move forward so with help from people just like you we will be able to provide this worker focused employment opportunity for other people just like Danny. Danny thanks you for reading our story, sharing it with others and for supporting him at Poppin' Z's Gourmet Popcorn. 

Thank you for helping Danny's dreams come true!

Wow! We're were on TV!

Local Popcorn Business empowers son with disabilities in the Green Bay Press Gazette ~ Sept. 2017  http://www.greenbaypressgazette.com/media/cinem...

Doing the Right Thing segment on WFRV ~ July 2016  http://www.wearegreenbay.com/community/doing-th...

National Caramel Popcorn Day with Local 5 Live on WFRV  ~ April 2018  http://www.wearegreenbay.com/local-5-live/local...

"Popcorn with a Purpose" is our slogan. We believe the opportunities are much more than making popcorn. As a mom of a young man who doesn't have the ability to assess harmful or dangerous situations I worry about him being alone in public spaces or under in-direct supervision. I know this concern is shared by many special needs parents as well. By providing a safe work environment with direct supervision by people who truly understand the needs of the individual the opportunity to thrive is not left to chance. 

Poppin' Z's is a worker focused company which means focusing on the persons strengths and providing the necessary tools or assistance to help them become successful. Our work experience provides more than an opportunity to improve job skills but to develop friendships, self-esteem and self-worth. For many people with special needs having friends who truly accept you for who you are is a rare gift. Working in a place where others focus on what you can do rather than what you can't seems like common sense but isn't always practiced in the work place. Opportunities to develop meaningful job skills, independence, develop friendships, and to be accepted for who you are and who you want to become are a few of the "purposes" behind our popcorn. 

For a growing business the challenges are ever changing. We currently rent a space we "retro-fitted" into a commercial kitchen which met our needs in the beginning, however we are quickly outgrowing. This space is in an old strip mall where any electrical or plumbing improvements can't be done to an individual space without bringing the entire building up to code which my landlord will not do.

 There is only one 220 outlet in my space which means I can either pop the corn or use the caramel cooker but I can't do both.An additional 220 outlet would increase our production by allowing multiple tasks to be accomplished by workers at the same time which would decrease our costs significantly.

Our current space doesn't have a store front where customers can pick up their popcorn in a clean pleasant entrance rather than our current shared creepy back alley entrance. The space is not handicapped accessible which again the landlord can't correct without correcting the whole building. A store front type entrance would provide a business address for mail delivery and UPS pick ups, plus an identifiable location for social media.

We are simply outgrowing our space. When we are busy, our space is filled with workers making popcorn, labeling, packaging etc we simply do not have enough space for everyone to comfortably and safely maneuver around to complete their tasks. Our current space is 700 square feet. Our Big Dream is to have a commercial kitchen with approximately 1500 square feet. Storage space is limited to a 4 x 8 space for raw ingredients, supplies, packaging, etc., not much room for buying product in bulk. If we had more storage space we could buy raw ingredients and packaging in larger quantities which would lower our product costs. Storage for finished goods is limited as well especially during the busy holiday season. Thank heavens my business neighbor allows us to store our gift boxes on a few of his shelves during that crazy busy season.

Simply put we would like to build our own larger commercial kitchen that is handicap accessible, meets current building codes with multiple 220 outlets for our current equipment. Our new kitchen layout is more than twice our current size, provides ample work space, improves work flow, improves storage and creates a new showroom or store front. WhoHoo!!!

Here's our preliminary kitchen design.

Here's our preliminary cost estimation.

Areas of Construction completely financed: drywall, windows,

We are so much more than popcorn. Popcorn with a Purpose is more than our company slogan. It is something we practice daily. 

Now I don't want to get too much into the weeds here but I feel I need to explain some of the challenges a person with a disability faces simply in finding a job. It's not easy even in today's growing economy. Employers often do not look past an individual's quirks or differences in order to take the chance in hiring that individual but don't we all have quirks and thank goodness we are all different.

When I started searching for options for Danny after high school and there weren't many in the area where we lived back then. I was startled by the sheltered workshops, basically the only available option in that area at that time. I didn't realize it at the time but this was a huge factor in starting our business.

I'm sure you've heard about some of the drawbacks for sheltered workshops - pay below minimum wage, repetitive work, lots of down time but for Danny it would provide a safe environment while developing some type of job skill in a team environment. I was cautiously optimistic back then. But something told me this was not the best option for Danny and our family so I kept looking and thinking "outside the box".

However, sheltered workshops are on the decline due to the supportive community employment movement for people with disabilities. But not everyone can be successful "out in the community" especially with limited supervision or no supervision. Danny couldn't but he does want to have a purpose and contribute. The National Council on Disability recommends phasing out all sheltered workshops, paying minimum wage, and believing that supported employment is not the end of a career but rather a stepping stone for greater self-sufficiency. 

Sounds promising doesn't it! However according to the Bureau of Labor Statics (2017) only 18.9% of people with any disability were employed compared to 65.7% of people without a disability. This report also stated the unemployment rate for people with any disability was 9.2% which is more than twice that of people without a disability (4.2%). This stat seemed really low to me and then I read that 8 out of 10 people with any disability are not even in the labor force compared with 3 out of 10 persons without a disability. So the stats aren't counting the majority of people with a disability who have given up on employment maybe because employers have given up on them. According to ARC Wisconsin 41% of individuals with an intellectual or developmental disability have a strong desire to be employed in a community based setting.Thankfully there are employers stepping up and these talented workers will have an opportunity for a better future.

Some things you may not know about employing a person with an intellectual or developmental disability.(Autism, Down Syndrome, traumatic brain injury are a few diagnosis that fall into this category.) Money is usually not a driving motivator for working. Taking pride in their work whatever the task and however menial we may think that task may be. Doing that task to the best of their ability is extremely important. They are very loyal workers who like being part of something. They want to have a purpose. They want to contribute. They want to have a place where they feel welcome and appreciated. Don't we all want these things?

However, if they can find employment it's usually limited to part-time perhaps due to the abilities of the individual but most often it's because they will lose their government benefits if they make too much money. 

Ok, that sounds reasonable. But I know some individuals who can only earn $60/month before they lose their government benefits which includes health insurance. How many employers do you know who provide health insurance for very part-time workers?

When I first started our business I worked with the Department of Work Force Development for months which resulted in a pile of paperwork and a job coach for Danny. Great!, I thought. Well, the job coach was assigned to Danny for a month which is a typical time frame, but due to Danny's earnings limit the job coach actually worked with Danny for 3-4 hours total. Think of your own job. Did you master it after 3-4 hours of training?

My guess is probably not. So why does "the system" expect that from people who have an intellectual disability? In fairness I could have re-applied for another session with another job coach (no guarantee Danny would have received the same coach) but the result would have been the same. The juice just wasn't worth the squeeze!

So now that you have a better understanding of a few of the barriers a person with a disability faces when looking for a job (and by no means have I covered everything), let's talk Poppin' Z's specifics and how we are trying to make a difference in our community for people with disabilities.

Poppin' Z's is a worker focused business which means matching the worker's abilities to the task, providing any modifications like a different type of scoop or providing assistance when needed. (continuous job coaching!) Our workers start out at minimum wage but like any business, our sales must cover that expense. We are a for-profit company so we often do not qualify for government grants or funds (subsidies) directed toward assisting people with disabilities like a sheltered workshop or adult day service program receives. (There are some advocates who are testing the waters to see if subsidies may be part of the employment puzzle but we'll see.)We want our workers to be able to earn a living wage but are well aware of the limitations "the current system" places on these individuals, as well as the risk for loosing important benefits. Hopefully "the system" will make the needed changes but we all are familiar with the speed of government.

Opportunities to be successful are happening daily at Poppin' Z's. Not only with job skill development but the soft skills many of us struggle with. How to have a conversation with friends? Learning the give and take of a conversation. What is appropriate to talk about plus how to use your tone of voice and body language. Being part of a team. Developing friendships. Spending time with people who accept you for who you are and who you want to become. How encouraging is that in your work environment! Encouraging you to do your best. Not perfect, not fast but just your best. It is the effort that is more important than the end product. Although our end product is pretty delicious!

Making popcorn might not be the "dream job" for some individuals who come through our doors but the skills they learn, the confidence in themselves and the belief that they belong will carry them well into whatever the future holds for them.

Creating our own licensed commercial kitchen space will create:

  • a safe working environment specially designed around the needs of the workers.
  • allow multiple tasks to be completed by multiple individuals at the same time
  • improve productivity
  • lower overall production costs
  • improves work flow and productivity
  • reduces worker anxiety
  • increases worker happiness
  • allow raw materials and goods to be purchased in greater volume
  • supported employment (continuous job coaching)
  • provide opportunities for success

 In March 2018, Wisconsin passed a bill called Employee First Initiative, which basically states any publicly funded program for people with disabilities who provides services or supports outside the home shall prioritize competitive integrated employment. It's too early to tell how this will improve employment for people with disabilities but I'm not waiting for policy to catch up to the many business, like ours, who value employees who work hard, enjoy their job, just happen to have a disability and who truly make a difference!

As a special needs parent there are more challenges in raising your child than anyone not in our shoes can ever imagine. Like all parents we do not stop "championing" our children once they become adults but special needs parents continuously advocate for a quality of life there children deserve.

Challenges often are unexpected despite careful planning. Remaining calm, considering your options and taking appropriate action will help overcome any challenge we may face on our journey. 

Owning a small business is inherently a risky proposition but without great risk there isn't great reward, right? Now that doesn't mean I'm a skydiving dare devil (my friends are laughing hysterically right now). I'm a cautious think this through, work hard, yes it's gonna work kind of risk taker. Danny is my motivation and I'm a persistent patient mom who is a determined advocate for both my children.

Have I thought about the specific risks and challenges for this project? Absolutely. Have I considered everything? Probably not. Will I be able to address the issue as they come up? Absolutely. Will the project dissolve if we don't raise enough money? Absolutely not. Continuously working toward your goal often requires an alternate path or a new technique in order to be successful and with your help we will be successful in more ways than a new commercial kitchen.

We are so appreciative and grateful for any help you can provide as we make this journey. Here are a few ideas to consider but feel free to create your own:

  • You can help by contributing to our campaign. Every bit helps and we truly do appreciate it.
  • You can help by sharing the information, crowdfunding link,  our web page https://poppinzsgourmetpopcorn.com  with others in your business or personal networks. (using the Indiegogo share tool makes it easy)
  • You can help by buying our popcorn throughout the year. Popcorn buffets for parties, employee appreciation, gifts, trade show giveaways, or just a special treat for family movie night. We truly do appreciate your business!
  • You can help by supporting businesses, like ours, who support people with disabilities in your area.
  • You can help by taking a few moments in your day to have a conversation with someone with a disability. The smile and friendship will definitely make your day!

Thank you for taking the time to view this information and for making a difference! We truly do appreciate it!

P is for Perks and Popcorn of course.

Here is a more detailed description of what you will receive with your donation. We are truly grateful for any help you are able to provide including sharing our information with others. Thank you!

 Popcorn Buddy $10 ~ Thank you note, our e-newsletter, a social media shout out.

 Popcorn Friend $25 ~ a coupon for a free family bag of popcorn (you choose flavor), Thank you note, our e-newsletter, a social media shout out.

 Popcorn Trooper $50 ~ our new mascot Elmer Elephant, a cute t-shirt, plus a regular size bag of popcorn (you choose flavor), your name on our Popcorn Friends display, plus an invite to our grand opening Popcorn Party.

 Popcorn Hero $100 ~ A gift box to be sent now or a gift certificate for later. Choose from our Caramel Lovers (caramel, caramel apple, Green Bay mix), Cheese Lovers (cheddarific, garlic parmesan, baconator),, Wisconsin Sports pack (Green & Gold, Badgerland, Brewer's Pride). Gift certificate can be redeemed anytime in the next year. Our new mascot Elmer Elephant, a cute t-shirt, your name on our Popcorn Friends display, plus an invite to our grand opening Popcorn Party.

 Popcorn Champion $250 ~ Be a champion with your friends and family by bringing our premium popcorn buffet to your next party. Choose a gift certificate where you can choose your flavor options or pick the Caramel Drizzle, Green Bay Mix, and White Cheddar option to be sent now. A gift certificate for a gift box is a great gift idea or something special for you. Our new mascot Elmer Elephant, a cute t-shirt, your name on our Popcorn Friends display, plus an invite to our grand opening Popcorn Party.

 Popcorn VIP $500 ~ a Very Important Popcorn Person! Celebrate with a SS Combo buffet certificate redeemable for your next office or family party plus a gift certificate for 3 gift boxes (choose one of our combos or design your own). A donation to The Giving Tree which is an organization that helps feed low income families in the Green Bay area. Your name prominently displayed on our Popcorn Friends display, plus an invite to our grand opening Popcorn Party, our new mascot Elmer Elephant, a cute t-shirt, e-newsletter, thank you with our deepest appreciation!

 Popcorn Executive $1000 ~ a top Popcorn Executive receives our popcorn of the month club for 1 year. A different gift box each month filled with seasonal popcorn favorites. A gift certificate for a SS Combo buffet perfect for weddings or employee appreciation or corporate events. A donation to Special Olympics Wisconsin (Danny is a participant and he loves it!)Your name prominently displayed on our Popcorn Friends display, plus an invite to our grand opening Popcorn Party, our new mascot Elmer Elephant, a cute t-shirt, e-newsletter, thank you with our deepest appreciation!

When I started searching for options for Danny after high school and there weren't many in the area where we lived back then. I was startled by the sheltered workshops, basically the only available option in that area at that time. I didn't realize it at the time but this was a huge factor in starting our business.
I'm sure you've heard about some of the drawbacks for sheltered workshops - pay below minimum wage, repetitive work, lots of down time but for Danny it would provide a safe environment while developing some type of job skill in a team environment. I was cautiously optimistic back then. But something told me this was not the best option for Danny and our family so I kept looking and thinking "outside the box".
However, sheltered workshops are on the decline due to the supportive community employment movement for people with disabilities. But not everyone can be successful "out in the community" especially with limited supervision or no supervision. Danny couldn't but he does want to have a purpose and contribute. The National Council on Disability recommends phasing out all sheltered workshops, paying minimum wage, and believing that supported employment is not the end of a career but rather a stepping stone for greater self-sufficiency. 
Sounds promising doesn't it! However according to the Bureau of Labor Statics (2017) only 18.9% of people with any disability were employed compared to 65.7% of people without a disability. This report also stated the unemployment rate for people with any disability was 9.2% which is more than twice that of people without a disability (4.2%). This stat seemed really low to me and then I read that 8 out of 10 people with any disability are not even in the labor force compared with 3 out of 10 persons without a disability. So the stats aren't counting the majority of people with a disability who have given up on employment maybe because employers have given up on them. According to ARC Wisconsin 41% of individuals with an intellectual or developmental disability have a strong desire to be employed in a community based setting.Thankfully there are employers stepping up and these talented workers will have an opportunity for a better future.
Some things you may not know about employing a person with an intellectual or developmental disability.(Autism, Down Syndrome, traumatic brain injury are a few diagnosis that fall into this category.) Money is usually not a driving motivator for working. Taking pride in their work whatever the task and however menial we may think that task may be. Doing that task to the best of their ability is extremely important. They are very loyal workers who like being part of something. They want to have a purpose. They want to contribute. They want to have a place where they feel welcome and appreciated. Don't we all want these things?
However, if they can find employment it's usually limited to part-time perhaps due to the abilities of the individual but most often it's because they will lose their government benefits if they make too much money. 
Ok, that sounds reasonable. But I know some individuals who can only earn $60/month before they lose their government benefits which includes health insurance. How many employers do you know who provide health insurance for very part-time workers?
When I first started our business I worked with the Department of Work Force Development for months which resulted in a pile of paperwork and a job coach for Danny. Great!, I thought. Well, the job coach was assigned to Danny for a month which is a typical time frame, but due to Danny's earnings limit the job coach actually worked with Danny for 3-4 hours total. Think of your own job. Did you master it after 3-4 hours of training?
My guess is probably not. So why does "the system" expect that from people who have an intellectual disability? In fairness I could have re-applied for another session with another job coach (no guarantee Danny would have received the same coach) but the result would have been the same. The juice just wasn't worth the squeeze!
So now that you have a better understanding of a few of the barriers a person with a disability faces when looking for a job (and by no means have I covered everything), let's talk Poppin' Z's specifics and how we are trying to make a difference in our community for people with disabilities.
Poppin' Z's is a worker focused business which means matching the worker's abilities to the task, providing any modifications like a different type of scoop or providing assistance when needed. (continuous job coaching!) Our workers start out at minimum wage but like any business, our sales must cover that expense. We are a for-profit company so we often do not qualify for government grants or funds (subsidies) directed toward assisting people with disabilities like a sheltered workshop or adult day service program receives. (There are some advocates who are testing the waters to see if subsidies may be part of the employment puzzle but we'll see.)We want our workers to be able to earn a living wage but are well aware of the limitations "the current system" places on these individuals, as well as the risk for loosing important benefits. Hopefully "the system" will make the needed changes but we all are familiar with the speed of government.
Opportunities to be successful are happening daily at Poppin' Z's. Not only with job skill development but the soft skills many of us struggle with. How to have a conversation with friends? Learning the give and take of a conversation. What is appropriate to talk about plus how to use your tone of voice and body language. Being part of a team. Developing friendships. Spending time with people who accept you for who you are and who you want to become. How encouraging is that in your work environment! Encouraging you to do your best. Not perfect, not fast but just your best. It is the effort that is more important than the end product. Although our end product is pretty delicious!
Making popcorn might not be the "dream job" for some individuals who come through our doors but the skills they learn, the confidence in themselves and the belief that they belong will carry them well into whatever the future holds for them.
Creating our own licensed commercial kitchen space will create:

a safe working environment specially designed around the needs of the workers.
allow multiple tasks to be completed by multiple individuals at the same time
improve productivity
lower overall production costs
improves work flow and productivity
reduces worker anxiety
increases worker happiness
allow raw materials and goods to be purchased in greater volume
supported employment (continuous job coaching)
provide opportunities for success

 In March 2018, Wisconsin passed a bill called Employee First Initiative, which basically states any publicly funded program for people with disabilities who provides services or supports outside the home shall prioritize competitive integrated employment. It's too early to tell how this will improve employment for people with disabilities but I'm not waiting for policy to catch up to the many business, like ours, who value employees who work hard, enjoy their job, just happen to have a disability and who truly make a difference!

As a special needs parent there are more challenges in raising your child than anyone not in our shoes can ever imagine. Like all parents we do not stop "championing" our children once they become adults but special needs parents continuously advocate for a quality of life there children deserve.
Challenges often are unexpected despite careful planning. Remaining calm, considering your options and taking appropriate action will help overcome any challenge we may face on our journey. 
Owning a small business is inherently a risky proposition but without great risk there isn't great reward, right? Now that doesn't mean I'm a skydiving dare devil (my friends are laughing hysterically right now). I'm a cautious think this through, work hard, yes it's gonna work kind of risk taker. Danny is my motivation and I'm a persistent patient mom who is a determined advocate for both my children.
Have I thought about the specific risks and challenges for this project? Absolutely. Have I considered everything? Probably not. Will I be able to address the issue as they come up? Absolutely. Will the project dissolve if we don't raise enough money? Absolutely not. Continuously working toward your goal often requires an alternate path or a new technique in order to be successful and with your help we will be successful in more ways than a new commercial kitchen.

We are so appreciative and grateful for any help you can provide as we make this journey. Here are a few ideas to consider but feel free to create your own:

You can help by contributing to our campaign. Every bit helps and we truly do appreciate it.
You can help by sharing the information, crowdfunding link,  our web page https://poppinzsgourmetpopcorn.com  with others in your business or personal networks. (using the Indiegogo share tool makes it easy)
You can help by buying our popcorn throughout the year. Popcorn buffets for parties, employee appreciation, gifts, trade show giveaways, or just a special treat for family movie night. We truly do appreciate your business!
You can help by supporting businesses, like ours, who support people with disabilities in your area.
You can help by taking a few moments in your day to have a conversation with someone with a disability. The smile and friendship will definitely make your day!

Thank you for taking the time to view this information and for making a difference! We truly do appreciate it!

P is for Perks and Popcorn of course.
Here is a more detailed description of what you will receive with your donation. We are truly grateful for any help you are able to provide including sharing our information with others. Thank you!
 Popcorn Buddy $10 ~ Thank you note, our e-newsletter, a social media shout out.
 Popcorn Friend $25 ~ a coupon for a free family bag of popcorn (you choose flavor), Thank you note, our e-newsletter, a social media shout out.
 Popcorn Trooper $50 ~ our new mascot Elmer Elephant, a cute t-shirt, plus a regular size bag of popcorn (you choose flavor), your name on our Popcorn Friends display, plus an invite to our grand opening Popcorn Party.
 Popcorn Hero $100 ~ A gift box to be sent now or a gift certificate for later. Choose from our Caramel Lovers (caramel, caramel apple, Green Bay mix), Cheese Lovers (cheddarific, garlic parmesan, baconator),, Wisconsin Sports pack (Green & Gold, Badgerland, Brewer's Pride). Gift certificate can be redeemed anytime in the next year. Our new mascot Elmer Elephant, a cute t-shirt, your name on our Popcorn Friends display, plus an invite to our grand opening Popcorn Party.
 Popcorn Champion $250 ~ Be a champion with your friends and family by bringing our premium popcorn buffet to your next party. Choose a gift certificate where you can choose your flavor options or pick the Caramel Drizzle, Green Bay Mix, and White Cheddar option to be sent now. A gift certificate for a gift box is a great gift idea or something special for you. Our new mascot Elmer Elephant, a cute t-shirt, your name on our Popcorn Friends display, plus an invite to our grand opening Popcorn Party.
 Popcorn VIP $500 ~ a Very Important Popcorn Person! Celebrate with a SS Combo buffet certificate redeemable for your next office or family party plus a gift certificate for 3 gift boxes (choose one of our combos or design your own). A donation to The Giving Tree which is an organization that helps feed low income families in the Green Bay area. Your name prominently displayed on our Popcorn Friends display, plus an invite to our grand opening Popcorn Party, our new mascot Elmer Elephant, a cute t-shirt, e-newsletter, thank you with our deepest appreciation!
 Popcorn Executive $1000 ~ a top Popcorn Executive receives our popcorn of the month club for 1 year. A different gift box each month filled with seasonal popcorn favorites. A gift certificate for a SS Combo buffet perfect for weddings or employee appreciation or corporate events. A donation to Special Olympics Wisconsin (Danny is a participant and he loves it!)Your name prominently displayed on our Popcorn Friends display, plus an invite to our grand opening Popcorn Party, our new mascot Elmer Elephant, a cute t-shirt, e-newsletter, thank you with our deepest appreciation!

story:
This is the 4th wave of coffee 

In the last century the coffee culture around the globe changed dramatically. The 3rd wave brought up quality beans with a variety of tasty flavor profiles. Independent coffee shops with baristas became the trend. Different styles of brewing were introduced or rediscovered, improving the image of a filter coffee. Roasting became an artisan handcraft with roasters putting their fingerprint on the taste of coffee. Origin, organic coffee and direct trade became important. Check our FAQ to read more about all coffee waves.

Promises like fair trade, organic or small batch became abused by marketing and fail to deliver what is expected. Our understanding of these promises is simple, yet powerful:
We cooperate directly and face to face with our small partners in Colombia.

We dive deep into the world of coffee to find exceptional and rare coffees and deliver them to you. The result is our Red Manipura! Try it out and you will understand.

One of our partners in Colombia said "my coffee can be only as good as my neighbors'" - hence he is supporting and educating them. We believe this holds true in everything and this is why we cooperate with people who support their local communities and build something bigger than themselves. From the crop, to the packing, as well as the transportation and the delivery we take care that our products are as sustainable as it can get, while not making compromises in quality. Therefore, we use 100% recyclable packaging, we compensate CO2 and work with ecologically sustainable farms. We call this community supporting!

All this brings an exceptional cup of coffee into your life. The next time you enjoy your cup of coffee, take a deep breath and visualize the amount of interaction, knowledge and conviction which was put into bringing this product to you.

Now, this is what we call a mindful cup of coffee.

 

Redesigning the value distribution

Trading directly enables us to maximize transparency and to get rid of various middle men. This way we shift the value distribution back to the origin countries - generating as much social balance as possible.

 

 

Our Story

We are three friends, Michael, Rafael and Miguel, sharing the same passion for coffee and the vision to build a better world. 

In May 2018 we traveled to Colombia - Miguel's home country and home of the world's favorite arabica coffees. We were stunned by the prospering local coffee culture, the enthusiasm and the heart opening hospitality of the people. And we quickly realized the discrepancy between the picturesque life of a coffee farmer in our western consumer mind's imagination and the harsh reality they are facing daily.

We wanted to change this and started HandelsKontor Colonia.

 

 

The rising of a global coffee problem

While coffee is the second most traded product world wide, it is also a very controversial one. Global coffee trading aims for highly standardized coffee beans at low prices. This forces over production in the origin countries which leads to further decrease in prices and quality. The ones who suffer are the farmers and - in the long run - the consumers. 

 

 

The farmer's dilemma

Farmers are faced with rising living costs as well as the rising uncertainty of price stability for their harvested coffee. Due to over production of commodity coffee prices fall, making it nearly impossible for farmers to survive. 

As a result, thousands of farmers gave up their business in Colombia, thus contributing to social inequality. Some are even turning to coca, the source of cocaine. 

The coffee heritage dilemma

On the other hand, by giving up their farms, experience from coffee masters cultivating rare varieties of coffee is lost forever. This further contributes to the increase of commodity and blended coffees which in turn leads to further poverty in the origin countries. 

For the consumer, this means it will become more and more difficult to enjoy rare and exclusive coffee varieties.

Talking to Colombian coffee farmers and roasters, we could witness this development, but we were amazed to find out that there is a way out of this vicious circle.

 

Our Mission

We are sourcing unique and exceptional coffees for our customers with a focus on generating maximum value in the origin countries and creating a paradigm shift in the coffee culture.

Red Manipura

Working with our partners hand in hand allows us to build a strong personal network in Colombia and to find and collaborate with micro lot owners as well as experienced coffee masters who are passionate to create exceptional coffee varieties for us.

As an initial offering we kick start with a red honey processed coffee of the Arabica varietal Caturra - the Red Manipura. Worldwide shipping available! CO2 neutral in Germany, Add-on available for EU and rest of the world.

Prepared as pour over (V60/Chemex) or with the AeroPress, the coffee will have a sweet taste and bright, fruity aromas. It is never bitter and does not require sugar nor milk to be added. Preparing it with an Espresso machine (pressure of 9bar), will highlight the citrus aromas along with even stronger fruitiness and give you an intense reflection of the coffee fruit.

The production of honey processed coffee is more labor intense than for other coffees. Growing and processing is more delicate and mistake can easily damage the whole harvest. The drying and fermentation is risky because the coffee beans lie on raised beds for several weeks and, if not handled correctly, can rot easily. 

 

Every batch is unique and limited to the produced quantity of the farmer. The current series Red Manipura S.1906 was harvested in January 2019 and comes freshly roasted with only 500 bags available. 

As weather conditions change so does the taste of the coffee beans, hence every future batch will taste differently, carrying the distinct taste of nature in its soul.

 

Support Us

We made our homework, reached out and established strong connections. Now it is time for the next chapter.

With your support we will

  • establish a sustainable order quantity
  • proof to our partners that the market demand is there
  • finance the education and setup costs for smaller farms to grow specialty coffee  
  • pay a premium to the ones collecting the coffee
  • establish new connections and bring more awesome coffee to your homes
    e.g. mandarin fermentation or rum barrel aged

 

 

Perk "Red Manipura S.1906"

Back us up and receive exclusive offers on our first batch of Red Manipura coffee. The first batch consists of only 100 kg, which are 500 bags (200 grams each).

Get to know the amazing taste of our Colombian honey processed coffee and fall in love with it. You will not regret it.

Contribute now and with your next cup of coffee you will improve the lives of many hard-working farmers, workers and their families!

 

 

Perk "Coffee Adventure"

Have you ever dreamed of visiting a coffee farm in Colombia and learning the basics about coffee? Well... this is your chance NOW!  

Contributing to this perk you can either bid for a secured spot or take part in our lottery and

JOIN US ON A 1-WEEK TRIP TO COLOMBIA

where you learn everything about coffee from growing to roasting and see some of Colombia's most beautiful and hidden spots. 

From Bogota we will go to Manizales to visit our partners. We spent time in the coffee zone (zona cafetera), learning everything about coffee: from the tree school, the picking and processing in the Finca. You will get to know the farmers and enjoy amazing chatting.

We also visit the roastery, where you will learn everything about the art of roasting coffee. You will be taking part in a coffee tasting (cupping) - professionally sipping a cup of coffee, prepared by the master roaster himself.

Sight seeing and gaining cultural insights will be part of the journey as well. You will visit beautiful places and hidden spots and see Colombia from the eyes of a local.

You have two options: 

  • Guaranteed - book a secured spot and you will be in Colombia with us. 
  • Lottery - join the lottery and get the chance to win a spot for this adventure.

What's included:

  • Transportation from/and to Bogota Airport
  • All ground transportation after leaving Bogota Airport
  • Accommodation
  • Visits to coffee farms and a roastery
  • 3 meals a day
  • water and soft drinks
  • Coffee (obviously)

 

 

Other Ways You Can Help

You like our mission but don't drink coffee? No problem! You can help us to spread the word. Use the Indiegogo sharing tools or like and share our instagram posts: @handelskontorcolonia

You can also make a donation which will earn you our eternal gratitude! 
And, if you're around either Cologne or Aachen, Germany and would like to enjoy a cup of coffee and good conversation come around and visit us!

 

 

Make Coffee Great Again!

story:
Our newest adventure-Lucky Paw Distillery!

Chris and Katie are hoping to become the first craft distillery since prohibition in Eastern Baltimore County Maryland in Middle River/White Marsh, offering premium: tours, tastings, a tap room and events. 

Chris and Katie fell in love with the art, process and products of distilleries while visiting other distilleries over the years. While Katie was in school pursuing a Doctorate in Education, Chris felt unhappy in his current career and thought what a better time than now to start his dream job!

The name Lucky Paw is special to us because of a dog Chris and Katie named ‘Lucky’! Before owning dogs of their own, Chris and Katie met Lucky.  One rainy night while driving, Lucky ran out in front of Chris and Katie almost getting hit, hence the name Lucky.  After chasing Lucky down and brining him home to find his owners, Chris and Katie knew this was a sign that they must continue to help rescues dogs and animals.  Lucky Paw Distillery will help Chris and Katie combine their two loves-animals and spirits!

Working with local farmers and business to get supplies and ingredients, making sure Lucky Paw Distillery stays true to the ‘grain to glass’ philosophy.  Focusing on small batch, hand-crafted spirits will allow Lucky Paw Distillery to ensure quality over quantity, as well as, allowing for more variety of flavors.  Lucky Paw Distillery intends to be environmentally conscious in the production process, by recycling water and making dog biscuits from the excess grain.  The location will be in the Middle River/White Marsh area due to the accessibility from all over the county; specifically, the close proximity to Interstate 695/95.

Our mission:  To create unique small batch spirits and premium tastings derived from local ingredients while providing a warm, welcoming environment for our two and four legged friends.

Chris and Katie want you, our family and friends, the locals and our community to enjoy quality spirits as much as us, right in our backyard.  Chris and Katie will host frequent adoption and fundraising events for local shelters and rescues.

Would you be generous enough to make a donation to help make Chris and Katie’s dreams a reality?

Come visit us soon at Lucky Paw Distillery!
